Identifying Characteristics: 2 color variations: red dorsal stripe that tapers towards the tail or lacking almost all red color
Red stripe can also be yellow, orange, or white
Between 19 and 20 folds on their sides
Small legs with short, thick toes
The five hind toes are slightly webbed and there are 4 toes on forefeet
They have the ability to drop all or part of their tail if under attack from a predator and re-grow a new one—the tail that grows back is often lighter in color
Size: Average adults are around 7.5cm long
Biology: Sexual maturity occurs after about 2 years
Mating season runs from October until December
Male deposits spermatophores that are later recovered by the female in her cloaca
Female lay eggs between June and July
Eggs are typically deposited in clusters of 3-13
Clusters are held together and suspended from the ceiling of the nest—is usually a rotted out log or any available crevice
Female tend the eggs until they hatch
There is no aquatic larval stage
Gills reach full development before the larva hatches from its egg envelope but only persist a few days after hatching In the redbacked phase-the dorsal band is well developed by the time of hatching
In the redbacked phase-the dorsal band is well developed by the time of hatching
Males have a more swollen snout, enlarged premaxillary teeth, and proportionally longer legs
Males are generally smaller than females in body length
Diet: Invertebrates including flies, spiders, snails, earthworms, ants, insects, mites, centipedes, millipedes, beetles, snails, and larvae
Range: Range is west to Missouri, south to North Carolina, and north from southern Quebec and the Maritime Provinces in Canada to Minnesota
